I.	DESCRIPTION OF THE FACILITY AND PURPOSE OF SUBMITTAL
Texas Barge and Boat, Inc. (Texas Barge and Boat) operates a marine terminal that primarily cleans and degasses marine tank barges, and will increase their propane storage capacity to facilitate flare operations. After expansion, Texas Barge and Boat will store up to a total capacity of 4,000 gallons.  Chemicals handled at the facility include hydrocarbons/petroleum products, solvents, intermediates, and industrial products.  The terminal is located on the Brazos River approximately three miles south of Freeport. In accordance with U.S. Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) regulations in Title 40 Code of Federal Regulations Part 68 (40 CFR 68), the U.S. EPA has identified quantities for 77 toxic substances and 63 flammable substances that require a facility to comply with the Risk Management Program (RMP) rules when unit inventories exceed threshold quantities.  The RMP rules require a facility to report the unit inventory for each RMP substance that exceeds threshold quantities, along with an EPA-approved chemical release prevention program.  In addition, 40 CFR 68 requires all RMP-covered facilities to update its Risk Management Plan (RMP Plan) within (6) months of an RMP reportable incident or every five (5) years, whichever comes first.  Per 40 CFR §68.190(b)(3), an update to the RMP is required no later than the date on which a new regulated substance is first present above its threshold quantity.  This is the initial submittal of the RMP Plan for Texas Barge and Boat.
40 CFR 68 requires all facilities subject to the rule to conduct an Offsite Consequence Analysis (OCA) to provide information to the public as well as state and federal environmental agencies about potential consequences of an accid

ental chemical release.  OCAs are essential in identifying potential hazards of an accidental release.  OCAs can include a Worst-Case Scenario (WCS) and an Alternate Release Scenario (ARS).  This submission includes OCAs of both the WCS and ARS for propane (PROPANE), a toxic chemical; it is the only chemical stored in excess of a threshold quantity as listed in 40 CFR 68 at the site.  Although numerous controls are in place to prevent chemical releases and manage such consequences should an incident occur, no credit for active mitigation measures was taken into account in evaluating these scenarios.
An OCA for the WCS was conducted using the EPA's RMP Guidance for Offsite Consequence Analysis, (EPA 550-B-99-009, April 1999).  The RMP sets forth specific criteria that must be incorporated in modeling the WCS.  The EPA defines a WCS as one that results in the greatest distance from the point of release to a specified endpoint.  As defined by the rule, the endpoint for a toxic substance is a specified concentration.
An ARS assesses the potential hazards that are more realistic than those associated with the worst-case scenario and is designed to assist in the development of emergency response plans.  The EPA RMP Guidance for Offsite Consequence Analysis was used in modeling the alternative release scenarios.  As required, an alternative release scenario was created for a toxic chemical release.
This is the initial submission of the RMP Plan for Texas Barge and Boat.  It is a requirement to update the RMP Plan within five (5) years of the initial submittal, no later than three years after a substance is first listed by EPA, or no later than the day on which a newly regulated substance is first present above the threshold level in a process that is already covered.

Development
The contents of the RMP Plan reflect compliance with federal and additional requirements that Texas Barge and Boat has deemed appropriate for accident prevention.  The document has been prepared on behalf of Texas Barge and Boat by Source Environmental Sciences, Inc.  The RMP Plan has been reviewed and approved by the Texas Barge and Boat management.
Periodic Review
As set forth in 40 CFR 68, this RMP Plan is periodically reviewed and amended as necessary, and every five (5) years as required by 40 CFR 68.  Revisions to this plan are made whenever applicable regulations are revised or added, or whenever there is a change in the facility's design, construction, operation, or maintenance that will affect the contents of the plan.  When a revision to a section is made, other sections affected by the change will be checked to assure continued accuracy and relevance.  An entire section is reissued whenever a change is made to any portion of the section.  In the event that all sections are reissued at one time, all sections will be reviewed completely.
A revision history will be maintained along with the plan and it is entitled Review and Revision History, which documents the changes made, the section number, revision date, effective date, and authorized signature of the person approving the section.  Obsolete original pages and obsolete revision history pages will be maintained for a period of three (3) years in the Texas Barge and Boat environmental records.  All amendments, revisions, and updates will be made in accordance with the requirements in 40 CFR 68.

XII.	PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY
Texas Barge and Boat continually strives to improve its safety related systems.  Its policies and procedures provide the most efficient means to minimize environmental impacts on-site and to the public.  Texas Barge and Boat also continues to improve by implementing an incident investigation database to monitor potential risks of future incidents.  The improvements made by Texas Barge and Boat, along with monthly reviews of current safety protocols, reduce the risk of future incidents.

Texas Barge and Boat, Inc. (Texas Barge and Boat) operates a marine terminal that primarily cleans and degasses marine tank barges as well as blasting and coating of those barges.  During the degassing operations, many of the trace chemicals are burned up in a flare with propane fuel to ensure thorough burning. U.S. Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) regulations presented in Title 40 Code of Federal Regulations Part 68 (40 CFR 68), the Chemical Accident Prevention Provisions, require Texas Barge and Boat to comply with the Risk Management Program (RMP) rule because the quantities of propane to be stored onsite exceed threshold quantities.
The RMP rule requires a facility to report the unit inventory for each RMP substance that exceeds threshold quantities, along with an EPA-approved chemical release prevention program. II.	PROGRAM 1, 2, AND 3 ELIGIBILITY REQUIREMENTS
Program 1 eligibility requirements apply to a process if no accidental release of a regulated substance has lead to death, injury, or deleterious effects to an environmental receptor, if the distance to a toxic or flammable endpoint for a worst-case release assessment is less than the distance to any public receptor, and if emergency response procedures have been coordinated between the source and the local emergency planning and response organizations.
Program 3 applies if the process does not meet the applicability requirements of Program 1 and if (1) the process is in a specific Standard Industrial Code category (see list of specific SIC codes in 40 CFR 68) and/or (2) the process is subject to the OSHA process safety management standard (29 CFR §1910.119).
Program 2 applies if the eligibility requirements of Program 1 and 3 are not met for a covered process.
The Texas Barge and Boat Terminal operations are subject to Program 1 requirements because of the following conditions.
1.	No release of a regulated substance has lead to death, injury, or deleterious effects on an environmental receptor.
2.	The flammable endpoint for a worst-case release assessment is less than distance to an environmental receptor
3.	The NAICS code of the facility is 336611 Ship Building and Repairing.  This industrial designation is not specifically listed as being subject to Program 3 requirements in 40 CFR §68.10(d)(1) and because no process at the Texas Barge and Boat Terminal is subject to an OSHA PSM standard (29 CFR §1910.119).

IV.	SCOPE OF PLAN

rmation is provided, and site-specific information for Texas Barge and Boat is presented.  At a minimum, all personnel handling the chemicals included in this RMP are trained in the operations and maintenance of equipment to prevent releases; release procedure protocols; applicable pollution control regulations; general facility operations; and the concepts embodied by this RMP Plan.  Additionally, release prevention briefings are scheduled and conducted for personnel at least once a year to assure adequate understanding of the concepts that form the components of the RMP Plan.  The release prevention briefings highlight and describe known discharges or failures, malfunctioning components, and any recently-developed precautionary measures.
Operator Training
Operators must demonstrate successful completion of the following release-related tasks:
a.	Operation of Outfalls 02, 03 and B03,
b.	Operation of dike valves for release of rainwater,
c.	Response to releases in drainage system, (settling pond, which discharges to the Brazos River) and,
d.	Operation of electric and diesel drainage pumps.
Security and Site Access
Texas Barge and Boat is protected by a 6-foot high chain-link fence topped by barbed wire on the land-side perimeter.  
Personnel and vehicles enter/exit through gates.  Entry/exit in those areas protected only by natural barriers is controlled in two ways:
¿	Routine patrols by operating personnel or contract security guards.
¿	Posted signs reading Restricted Area
Adequate lighting is provided at the facility to assist in the discovery and control of a release occurring during hours of darkness, both by operating personnel, if present, and by non-operating personnel (the general public, local police, etc.).  Adequate lighting is provided to prevent a release from occurring through acts of vandalism.

Alternative Release Scenarios
Alternative Release Scenarios (ARS) assess the potential hazards that are more realistic than worst-case scenar

ios and are designed to assist in the development of emergency response plans.  EPA's RMP Guidance for OCA and RMP*Comp were used in evaluating the alternative release scenarios for propane.  The consequences of these scenarios were calculated using the RMP*Comp.  Although numerous controls are in place to prevent chemical releases and manage such consequences should an incident occur, no credit for active mitigation measures was taken into account in evaluating these scenarios. 
Alternative Release Scenario - Flammable Substance
The alternative release scenario of propane would occur if there were a vapor cloud fire caused by a punctured tank.  The amount of propane released from a 4 square inch puncture 1 foot below the liquid line is calculated as follows:
QR=HA×6.82√(11.7/〖DF〗^2 ×LH+669/DF×P_g )
	Where:		QR =	Release Rate (lb/min)
			HA = 	Hole or puncture area (square inches), estimated at 4 square inches
			DF = 	Density factor, from RMP Guidance for OCA Appendix C
				0.83 for Propane
			LH = Height of liquid column above hole (inches), estimated at 12 inches
			Pg =	Gauge pressure of the tank pressure (psig), 121 psig for propane	
QR=4×6.82√(11.7/〖(0.83)〗^2 ×12+669/0.83×121)
QR=8528.34 lb/min
Under this scenario, 8,528.34 lbs of propane would be released per minute, and the entire contents of the tank would be released in just under two minutes.  RMP*Comp estimates the distance to the lower flammability limit would be approximately 0.1 miles.

 
IX.	FIVE-YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY
The Texas Barge and Boat Terminal, in the past five (5) years, has not incurred any chemical releases that resulted in any known onsite or offsite deaths, injuries, significant damage, evacuations or sheltering in place, property damage, or environmental damage.

VII.	EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM
Information in this section is presented for Texas Barge and Boat in accordance with 40 CFR §68.95.  This section provides information concerning procedures for informing the public, first-aid, and procedures for emergency response.  Greater detail regarding these topics is included in the site's Emergency Response Plan/SPCC) Plan.
First Aid
The following information sources can be used to obtain information on chemicals and materials for first aid response.
a.	Material Safety Data Sheets (MSDS)
Texas Barge and Boat maintains MSDS that include response information for all chemicals within the facility.  Copies of the data sheets are to be readily available in designated places throughout the terminal.
b.	CHEMTREC (Chemical Transportation Emergency Center)
The CHEMTREC phone number is 800-424-9300.  CHEMTREC can be called for advice or assistance with any U.S. product.
Procedures for Emergency Response
a.	Texas Barge and Boat personnel and all plant departments have access to equipment at any time for use in responding to accidental release situations.  The equipment is readily available in the plant or from Texas Barge and Boat contractors for control and cleanup of releases.
b.	Should an emergency happen, the HSSE Coordinator will contact the Freeport Fire and Police Departments. 
c.	When appropriate, the HSSE Coordinator will contact an environmental response company contracted with Texas Barge and Boat to provide support (e.g. Heritage Environmental).

Personnel Training
Personnel training differs on the control structures, devices, and practices utilized; therefore, general training info

cated onsite for all personnel to review.  If a release occurs, arrangements are described in the Emergency Response Plan/SPCC Plan for notification of local emergency response agencies and the public.
Texas Barge and Boat is committed to operate and maintain its facility in a safe and environmentally-friendly manner.  Texas Barge and Boat complies with the RMP rules and regulations set forth by the U.S. EPA and even some elements of OSHA's Process Safety Management Program to ensure the safety of employees and public surroundings.  Texas Barge and Boat incorporates elements addressing the following:
Equipment Design - Vessels (including shipping containers) and other process equipment are designed according to recognized industry standards and/or governmental requirements.
Process Safety Information - Chemical hazard, process technology, and equipment information is documented, maintained up-to-date, and available to operating personnel.
Episodic Risk Management - Periodic reviews are conducted to identify hazards that could have significant community impact and to recommend corrective action(s) needed to prevent their occurrence.  These reviews utilize advanced quantitative risk assessment techniques.
Operational Safety Standards - Design requirements for active and passive mitigation controls used to prevent major process hazards are documented in operational safety standards.
Operating Procedures - Operating procedures provide detail on how to safely operate a process and are maintained up-to-date.
Operator Training Program - The plant has a training and testing program, which provides operators with the proper skills and knowledge prior to allowing them to independently operate a process.
Technical Staff Training and Support - Trained technical staff employees are available 24 hours a day to support operations.
Maintenance Procedures - The plant has specific procedures for maintaining process equipment so that it operates safely.
Maintenance Training

- The plant trains persons who perform routine maintenance tasks on process equipment.
Mechanical Integrity Program - Vessels (including shipping containers) and other process equipment are periodically tested and/or inspected to ensure safe operation of process equipment, following recognized industry standards and/or governmental requirements.
Incident Investigation - The plant has a program to ensure that accidents and incidents are properly investigated to determine the cause(s) and to implement corrective action(s) that are needed to prevent the event from reoccurring.
Employee Participation - The plant has a program to involve employees in prevention program elements. 
Compliance Audits - Periodic corporate and plant-led audits are conducted to ensure that process operations comply with governmental and corporate requirements.
Operational Safety Program - Oiltanking has a comprehensive program to ensure that all the elements listed above are implemented at every Oiltanking location. This program includes accountability for timely and proper implementation of the program elements.
These general prevention elements are parts of an overall management system to prevent accidental chemical releases.  Texas Barge and Boat and its employees are committed to the standards that these management systems set, and have specific accountability and controls to ensure that they are meeting their own high standards for accident prevention.
